intro: Apicra pentagona, commonly known as the five-sided grass, is a flowering plant native to certain regions of South America. It belongs to the Poaceae family, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and narrow leaves. The plant produces small, clustered inflorescences that are often overlooked due to their modest size. Its botanical significance lies in its unique leaf morphology, which features five distinct edges, giving it its common name. Apicra pentagona is often found in open, disturbed habitats and is of interest to botanists studying plant adaptation and diversity.
